Investigation 2

Common Multiple and Common Factor: Least or Greatest?

Many things happen over and over again in fixed cycles.

Here are some examples:

  • A morning news program gives a traffic report every 7 mintues.
  • A train arrives at a particular station every 30 minutes.
  • Felipe's smartwatch buzzes to remind him to stretch every 20 minutes.

If Felipe is at the train station, when will Felipe's watch alarm and the arrival of the train occur at the same time?

Since events like a train arriving every 30 minutes and Felipe's watch buzzing every 20 minutes occur in cycles, thinking about multiples helps to clarify what is happening.

Think about the multiples of 20 and 30.

  • The multiples of 20 are 20, 40, 60, 80, 100, 120, 140, 160, 180, ... 20N.
  • The multiples of 30 are 30, 60, 90, 120, 150, 180, ... 30N.

We can generalize the multiples of 20 with the expression 20N and the multiples of 30 with the expression 30N, where N is whole numbers. We can think of the expression 20N as a generator for the multiples of 20. That is, if we substitute all the whole numbers for N, we will produce all the multiples of 20. But since there are an infinite number of multiples of 20, it would be impossible to produce all of them.

The numbers 60, 120, 180, ... are multiples of both 20 and 30. These numbers are common multiplesof 20 and 30. The least common multiple (LCM) of 20 and 30 is 60. That is, the first multiple that is common to 20 and 30 is 60.

Now compare the factors of 20 and 30.

  • The factors of 20 are 1, 2, 4, 5, 10, and 20.
  • The factors of 30 are 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 10, 15, and 30.

The numbers 1, 2, 5, and 10 are factors of both 20 and 30. These numbers are common factors of 20 and 30. The greatest common factor (GCF) of 20 and 30 is 10.

At the end of the investigation, the idea of least common multiple or greatest common factor help us solve some interesting problems.
